Under Water Warfare represented c. £193m (c. 25% group sales) in 2017 of which a significant proportion was sonobuoy sales and Ultra sells to a number of countries including the UK. It is also worth noting that in 2016 sales to the US Navy represented $94m of Sparton’s ECP sales, although the allocation of production within the ERAPSCO JV is typically not 50%/50% and can change from year to year.

· Our current FY18E estimates include the Sparton acquisition and assume the deal completed on the 1 April 2018 and that Sparton contributes £13.7m of EBITA in 18E) which currently represents c. 10p of our EPS estimate for 2018E (Barclays 2018E EPS 127.0p, PER 11.6x; Thomson Reuters Eikon cons. EPS 118.0p, PER 12.5x).

The downside to the end of the deal is twofold. First, it sounds like a strategic setback with a rights issue decision coming too early. Second, it will lead to increased competition, as the US Navy is considering ways to increase competition. The upside is that Ultra could come out on top (Sparton may be weakened by the uncertainty about an acquisition). In addition, a new CEO (search is well underway) will not have to deal with the integration of a deal he/she did not spearhead.

CountryBoy @MouseletI imagine they probably have a better rating than if they listed in Georgia, also I think they have used the higher profile for international funding. The bits of BGEO that are going to be in the investment companies are decent sized businesses in the local market in property, healthcare, utilities and even brewing.
BE11:25am

Should also note that there's a bit of fiddling around with regards IFRS 15. Back to Caz.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

2018E EBITA – we trim by 6%: (1) Under IFRS 15 ULE’s 2017 EBITA would be £2.4m lower than reported, and this is the new base for 2018 guidance. (2) We now assume FX of $1.40/£ vs $1.30 previously, shaving c£2.5-3m off EBITA. (3) ULE guides to higher R&D in the coming years.

chad_john Probably not.
BE11:31am

Bovis continues to reset its business and get back on track. The new CEO is focusing on the right priorities, with 2017 results all broadly in line with expectations. There are clear targets out to 2020, with management sounding more confident and encouraging about where margins might get to over the medium term. Various initiatives on the margin front look promising and could potentially deliver margins above what is currently embedded in the land bank and expected by consensus for 2020. Cash generation has been good as the balance sheet has been squeezed, and supports the planned dividend payments.
Management will clearly remain focused on delivering against its 2020 targets and we are increasingly confident about it successfully reaching its c.18.5% operating margin target by 2020. The group is currently still significantly under-performing the industry average on margins and returns but is moving in the right direction. We have tweaked our estimates up mainly on higher margin assumptions and now expect PBT of £158m for 2018. The shares offer attractive dividends with a yield of 9% and clearly the P/NAV rating is pricing in a degree of the recovery that is underway.

undefined

BE11:32am

Okay, so should we get the Italian elections stuff out of the way?

Soundbuy sì
Paper Chase @#REF! One would assume that would be 0.45in, ie about 11mm or so.

Went as polls predicted with no clear majority but big gains for the populist types.

Quick line from Natixis.

BE11:35am

Although the M5S movement came out in the lead with 32% of votes, the right/extreme-right wing coalition formed by Mr. Berlusconi’s party, the Northern League, and Brothers of Italy, are thought to have won in total around 37% of votes (a partial outcome based on the results of two-thirds of polling stations).

BE11:35am

However, the right wing’s score is not high enough to obtain a majority in the national assembly, and this coalition will find it impossible to attract enough MPs from other groups to make up the shortfall.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

The coalition’s options are limited, and one of them includes cooperation between the M5S and La Lega… Our economists reckon that a grand coalition, formed around the PD and Forza Italia, is the most likely scenario (40% probability); however, the chances of Italy finding itself with an anti-euro government has increased significantly from 10% to 30%.

BE11:36am

And Exane.

red ital election mostly confined to italy. merkels win is what matters. euro flat on day which tells the story
Patience @#REF! - because of short barrel a handgun has a lower muzzle velocity than a rifle. So to get the same kinetic energy into the bullet it has to be much heavier, hence increase in diameter. Can't increase length because of gun size.
Flaneur read across for the UK - This has to weaken the EU esp in their Brexit negotiations. Disaster for EU.
BE11:36am

Investors had looked quite relaxed before the elections: the country spread vs Germany / Spain has been relatively stable YTD and the Italian market has slightly outperformed the euro area. A government led by a majority of the two moderate parties (PD and Forza Italia) is now off the table, while M5S+Lega could secure the majority of seats. The stronger-than-expected outcome for the populist parties could increase country risk and trigger some profit-taking on Italian stocks.

Soundbuy So, Itexit next............

BE11:37am

And HSBC.

Paper Chase I feel bad now for contributing to a discussion about guns. Let's talk about numbers going up and down instead.
BE11:37am

Recent market moves linked to 5SM-related news suggest that the initial market reaction is likely to be negative, particularly for the Italian equity and sovereign bond markets. With the strong display of both euro-sceptic parties, investors might fear a possible alliance between the NL and 5SM. The euro so far has not moved much, partly because the negative pressure from Italy could be offset by the announcement yesterday of a grand coalition in Germany, and also because of euro-sceptic parties in Italy have recently abandoned their pledge to leave the euro.

rw42 Isn't the risk in that whatever the EU negotiates each national govt has to agree to, and the wider range of politics in each country reduces the chance of the brexit deal being acceptable to all of them?
red italians arent too happy about euro but majority still want eu stays.
Flaneur (Soundbuy - personally I think there'll be civil trouble in Italy over this election.)
BE11:38am

For any 5SM-led government, as we discussed in our election preview, the key from an economic and market perspective would be if it retained a constructive dialogue with European authorities on fiscal policy issues and reforms, winning over some possible initial scepticism by other European politicians. As part of his team of Ministers candidates, Mr Di Maio announced that Andrea Roventini, a professor of economics who defines himself as "heretic Keynesian," would be the Finance Minister in a possible 5SM government. In an interview with Il Sole 24 Ore (1 March) Mr Roventini, although he maintained the party's line that EU fiscal rules should be relaxed, was conciliatory towards Brussels, arguing in favour of a "rigorous and credible approach" to fiscal policy and significant cuts to public spending to finance the 5SM's ambitious policies. And while the 5SM has dropped its pledge to have a referendum on the euro for this election, it still maintained this could still be a last resort in case Europe does not want to undertake the reforms Italy needs (ie. deeper integration, more flexibility on the fiscal rules, support on immigration…).

Mouselet I cannot help noticing that you have predicted eleven of the last zero revolutions
11:38 am
BE11:38am

The Litmus test would likely come in the spring (early May), when the European Commission will issue its updated fiscal recommendations to Italy, possibly demanding a further deficit reduction by cEUR3.5bn – 0.2% of GDP – for 2018, or later on with the 2019 budget law in the autumn. Obviously, any possible U-turns on key labour and pension reforms, which the party has recently hinted at, would also be major reasons for concern in Brussels, and also jeopardise the prospects for further European integration. With QE coming to an end and removing a key element of support to Italy’s sovereign bond markets, the margin of manoeuvre for the new Italian government is likely to be limited, and the market could react negatively to any early signs of a possible clash with European authorities.

Soundbuy My wife's quest for an Italian passport may be in vein.....
Mouselet "the reforms Italy needs include deeper integration" does not sound like strong Brexit support
red @Flaneureu is very fractured when it comes to what individual members want from a trade deal with the uk. its just we havent got there yet as the eu is demanding the uk sets out what it wants. it saves the eu a lot of hassle and infighting if the uk sets its stall out, that way the members arent seen to be dictating different terms.
BE11:39am

And Nomura .....

Mouselet But the whole point of the EU is that it will not make a trade deal with the UK which is unacceptable to any of its members!
BE11:39am

Based on what we know so far, on the back of preliminary results, there seems to be three possible next steps:
• 1) New elections: A potential failure in post-election coalition formation could lead to new elections – the first time Italy would experience back-to-back elections. Recent dynamics favour M5S and LN, so this would likely be taken as a negative for markets.
• 2) Centre-right and centre-left coalition: Although this scenario appears less likely as LN leads the centre-right, it could materialise if both sides agree that M5S should be kept away from power.
• 3) Anti-establishment coalition: According to the preliminary results, a coalition between M5S and LN (maybe with the help of Brothers of Italy) would have enough seats to reach a majority. There would need to be many political compromises made in such a scenario, and we struggle to see how LN would opt to take a back-seat in a populist party coalition with M5S (from being the largest party of the largest centre-right coalition and winner of the election).

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Two out of three of these scenarios would be very negative for the market, in our view, with only a centre-right/centre-left coalition considered market-friendly at this stage. However, the fact that in terms of seats the three biggest parties of such a coalition, i.e. PD, LN and FI, should be relatively close to each other, would make it difficult to agree on common policy. More than that, LN leader Matteo Salvini clearly expressed his opposition to such a coalition ahead of the election.

BE11:40am

The 10yr BTP-DBR spread has contracted from 150bp to 140bp since 23 February as the market priced out some tail risk around the election. The spread is likely to widen from the current level of 50% of the percentile back (and breaking) to the max of 150bp since the 10yr BTP was launched on 26 January as a first reaction to the results.

Flaneur @Mouse - thats just silly. But with side having a party being thats more or less outright rascist and the other wanting to break the italian state, this is bad for Eu no matter who 'governs'.
BE11:41am

And Citi.

Mouselet Yes, obviously this is the point at which the federal EU government should intervene and put a group of competent technocrats in charge, rather as the US would if West Carolina elected a majority of KKK members to the state senate
rw42 @flaneur/Mouselet - it might be silly but i suspect it's also true..
Mouselet But I think I may be more of a world-government enthusiast than is entirely central in this group
Mouselet I basically think that anything justified by 'sovereignty' rather than a real reason should just not be done
11:42 am
BE11:42am

While in the longer term Tomasi Di Lampedusa might still prove right as “for things to remain the same, everything must change”, in the short term we would expect an intense political agenda to explore new alliances. And [...] technicalities of Rosatellum make it very difficult to calculate votes and seats (final votes might be out by late tonight). More importantly, votes might not only have to be counted but also weighted to understand who might be entitled to try to create a government. As a starting point, Presidente Mattarella will have to give an explorative mandate to create a government to either Matteo Salvini (Lega, largest party in the largest coalition) or Luigi Di Maio (M5S, largest party overall). Assuming this is an easy task, then comes the challenging one : create an alliance with enough votes to support a stable government.

BE11:42am

While we would exclude a moderate government as highly unlikely at this stage (Berlusconi and Renzi should have just 40% of votes), we fear that a government center-right coalition would not last long given both the tensions betwen Salvini and Berlusconi over the last few months and most of all the surprising outcome. A centre-right government might anyhow struggle to attract more votes. On one hand, for example, Lega and PD are unlikely to agree on much, but it might be even more difficult for Berlusconi and M5S.

red @each member values each type of trade with the uk differently. some excel in certain areas, others less so.
Flaneur The real danger here is what Putin might do.I said it in jest earlier but ....... if he decides to 'stir' he could easily destabilise the whole place.
Mouselet Indeed; and hence you have a large complicated trade bureaucracy which eventually hammers out a deal which is then hammered into the trade partner
BE11:43am

Worringly for financial markets, Lega and M5S together will have more than 50% of votes (even not including FdI which is credited with nearly 4.5%). However, a government with such majority might also live only briefly given that Lega is strong in the richer north and M5S in the poorer south.
Finally, we can't exclude that in the end an alliance could be created between M5S, a part of PD and LEU. While these parties might share some views (especially on welfare), it would require a break-up of PD so is unlikely to come soon. Whatever the outcome, we do not see any positives for the markets. And considering that the enterprise value of the “Republic of Italy Inc.” is skewed to public debt which dwarfs equity market caps (which in turn is very exposed to financial stocks), investors should bear in mind: i) the probable paralysis of political parties somehow already preparing for the next political campaign (although we don’t expect a new round of elections in 2018); ii) the likely lack of reforms (short-term recessive and irreconcilable with what was promised in the campaigns); iii) public debt/GDP still north of 130% with no plan to reduce it given that all campaigns point to a widening deficit; iv) the likely end of QE; and v) the end of Mario Draghi’s tenure at the helm of the ECB.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Combining the above factors with the worrying demographics showing that nearly 30% of Italians are approaching 60 years old, we believe it is unlikely that financial markets will remain quiet in Italy.
While we agree that never-ending fear might be a more preferable scenario than a bad ending, we nonetheless would reduce exposure to Italian securities over the next few months.

Mouselet Lega feels to be occupying the same sort of role as an Independence for London and the South-East Party, which Britain has thankfully managed not quite to grow
Swedish Chef @mouse I suspect you will enjoy ‘soft border control’ on iplayer. BBC NI production, hilarious spoof documentary
Mouselet I ended up in tears of anger from old Yes Minister episodes, so I'm not utterly certain 'enjoy' is the verb :(
#REF! I've learned something from ML today. I mean about muzzle velocities not investments but hey ho
Mouselet The circumstances in which muzzle velocity knowledge and investment knowledge are useful don't overlap much, so think of it as widening your capabilities
BE11:45am

I, meanwhile, have no insight or even opinions about Italian politics. So I'll just say I agree with everything the ROTR's said and move on.

So ............ Monday, huh? I guess there's Axa.

Paying a silly price for XL, somewhat out of the blue.

BE11:48am

Shares getting smashed as a result. Down 7 or 8% last I checked.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

$15bn deal that seems to be opposite to everything management's said up to now.

Soundbuy Decent vols across the sector - guessing Mondi's results last week......
Soundbuy and GS this am.
BE11:50am

Citi:

BE11:50am

Ever since the plan to IPO the US operations was announced in May 2017, the market has been concerned about M&A risk and potential EPS dilution. Today’s acquisition of XL Group for €12.4bn (15x pre-synergy EPS, 11x post synergies and 2.0x TNAV) validates this. In the near term the price will be funded through cash of €3.5bn, US IPO and related proceeds of €6bn and sub debt of €3.0bn. No equity issuance is necessary and AXA will accelerate the US IPO with a 35% disposal now likely in Q2 18 and bridge financing is available if necessary. Assuming full divestment of the US by 2020, AXA will lose nearly 20% earnings (€1.2bn) to be replaced almost entirely by XL Group’s commercial lines P&C earnings (post synergies)

11:50 am
BE11:51am

While this deal is consistent with communicated objectives, it is bigger than we expected and rules out share buybacks in the near term. We had thought that bolt-on M&A in core markets more likely supplemented with buybacks. This deal looks expensive albeit genuinely transformative in commercial lines (adding €10bn of premium to existing commercial lines of €15bn plus another €5bn from reinsurance). AXA claims a 10% ROI which looks to be generously calculated. We estimate closer to 9% by 2020 post synergies and ignoring restructuring costs, which is disappointing given the somewhat volatile nature of XL’s earnings in recent years. Some of this volatility should be reduced through a different risk profile under AXA although this must also bring some dis-synergy potential. Expected capital benefits and potential to accelerate growth are the main sources of upside which could yet make this a more compelling deal over time.

BE11:51am

But enough of that.

undefined
11:52 am
BE11:52am

Okay .... so paper ............

BE11:53am

The reason I've been given for Smurfit being up nearly 4% is .... well, it's ludicrous. But it's not my job to apply editorial control onto explaining stock moves to here we go.

Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 2,534, up 104 (+4.28%), High: 2,542, Low: 2,450, Volume: 479.61k
11:55 am
DS Smith PLC (SMDS:LSE): Last: 476.50, up 16.7 (+3.63%), High: 477.40, Low: 459.40, Volume: 1.34m
Mondi PLC (MNDI:LSE): Last: 1,939, up 28 (+1.47%), High: 1,972, Low: 1,912, Volume: 685.36k
BE11:56am

There is, as noted on the right, a Goldman note around on the sector.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

We continue to prefer the structural thesis of packaging over
pulp/paper. The key elements in our view are: (1) pulp prices
rallied to all time-highs throughout 2017 and we expect
prices to fall as supply outgrows demand in 2018; (2) 2017
was a year of margin squeeze for packaging producers,
however we expect them to benefit from already achieved
price increases as well as strong demand; (3) online retail in
our view is positive for volumes and margins, which we
examine in more detail in this report. This is combined with
most of our pulp-exposed coverage trading at or close to
peak multiples despite pulp prices being at all-time highs,
and our top packaging exposed picks screen inexpensive in
comparison while having a more positive outlook.

BE11:57am

Buy Billerud, Smurfit and Mondi, Sell Stora and SCA

BE11:58am

And Citi's pushing Mondi post results.

hornblower missed the RNS at Mothercare Friday, going to run out of liquidity later this year. market cap down to £35m. debt, pension, leases, trade creditors total £550m. guidance PBT £1m
11:58 am
BE11:58am

Mondi has once again demonstrated its ability to handle inflationary pressures, through pricing power in supportive end markets and continued incremental efficiency gains from its extensive capex programmes.
